title.narrative: Save the Children activities in Syria and the region 2019

description.narrative: Save the Children activities in Syria and the region 2019
FL §06.39.03.11 Other contributions to acute and prolonged crises

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: Children and their families/caregivers recently displaced due to the escalation of conflict in NW Syria benefit from timely, safe, dignified and high-quality assistance to cover their basic physical and protection needs.

actual.value: A total of 1,618 MPCG was distributed in Syria reaching 8,351 individuals (1,525 male, 1,920 female, 2,407 girls, 2,499 boys). This was overachieved due to savings on salary lines that were allocated to MPGs line to increase the number of targeted HHs. 800 RTERs was distributed in Syria reaching 4,013 individuals (2,358 children, 1,655 adult) in their first two weeks after displacement.

title.narrative: Outcome 3.1: Barriers preventing vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of school children from accessing education are addressed

# of vulnerable IDP, refugees and returnees with access to safe and inclusive learning (360 (LEB: 160; JOR 200)
# of HHs supported with cash assistance with an aim to improve their children’s protection and access to education (350 (LEB 150; JOR 200)

target.value:
# of vulnerable IDP, refugees and returnees with access to safe and inclusive learning (360 (LEB: 160; JOR 200)
# of HHs supported with cash assistance with an aim to improve their children’s protection and access to education (350 (LEB 150; JOR 200)

actual.value:
374 (164 girls and 210 boys) accessed safe and inclusive learning (LEB 157; JOR 217).
390 HH was supported with cash assistance (LEB 173; JOR 217).

title.narrative: Outcome 2.1: Vulnerable conflict affected children have increased resilience

# of conflict-affected girls and boys participating in PSS and Resilience activities (2,130 (SYR 1,000; LEB 450; JOR 680))
# of girls and boys assisted through case management and referrals complimented with Individual Protection Assistance (830 (SYR 400; LEB 230; JOR 200)
% of girls and boys showing improvement in resilience and wellbeing (70)

target.value:
# of conflict-affected girls and boys participating in PSS and Resilience activities (2,130 (SYR 1,000; LEB 450; JOR 680))
# of girls and boys assisted through case management and referrals complimented with Individual Protection Assistance (830 (SYR 400; LEB 230; JOR 200)
% of girls and boys showing improvement in resilience and wellbeing (70)

actual.value:
6,084 (2,895 girls and 3,189 boys) conflict affected girls and boys participated in PSS and Resilience activities (SYR 4,787; LEB 479; JOR 818).
1,139 (448 girls and 691 boys) children were assisted through case management and referrals complimented with individuals Protection Assistance (SYR 625; LEB 297; JOR 217)
88% of girls and boys showed improvement in resilience and wellbeing.

title.narrative: Outcome 2.3: The capacity of communities and local actors are strengthened to respond to CP and psychosocial needs of conflict affected children

# of CP committees (CPCs) established, trained and active (7 (JOR 2; SYR 5))
% CPC members with increased knowledge in CP, PFA, Safe Identification and Referral, mobilization, rapid assessment, facilitation skills, advocacy, GBV indicators & gender equality, inclusion (JOR 70%; SYR: 50%).
# of partner staff trained on CP principles and the risks of harmful work and child marriage (32 (LEB 12; JOR 20)
# of individuals reached through awareness raising campaigns on child rights, the negative impact of harmful work and child marriage (6,430 (SYR 4,000; LEB 510; JOR 1920).

target.value:
# of CP committees (CPCs) established, trained and active (7 (JOR 2; SYR 5))
% CPC members with increased knowledge in CP, PFA, Safe Identification and Referral, mobilization, rapid assessment, facilitation skills, advocacy, GBV indicators & gender equality, inclusion (JOR 70%; SYR: 50%).
# of partner staff trained on CP principles and the risks of harmful work and child marriage (32 (LEB 12; JOR 20)
# of individuals reached through awareness raising campaigns on child rights, the negative impact of harmful work and child marriage (6,430 (SYR 4,000; LEB 510; JOR 1920).

actual.value:
7 CP committees was established, trained and active (JOR 2; SYR 5)
In Syria, 74% of the CPC members had increased their knowledge whereas in Jordan, the figure was 90%.
38 partner staff (29 women and 9 men) were trained (LEB 16; JOR 22)
8,401 (4,591 females and 3,810 males) reached through awareness raising campaigns on child rights, the negative impact of harmful work and child marriage (SYR 5,787; LEB 553; JOR 2,061)

title.narrative: Outcome 3.2: Enrolled children benefit from a quality learning educational environment

# of teachers trained on basic literacy and numeracy, child-centered pedagogy, classroom management methods (LEB 8)
% of targeted girls and boys who demonstrate an improvement in literacy and numeracy levels (70)

target.value:
# of teachers trained on basic literacy and numeracy, child-centered pedagogy, classroom management methods (LEB 8)
% of targeted girls and boys who demonstrate an improvement in literacy and numeracy levels (70)

actual.value:
8 teachers (7 females and 1 male) were trained
76.5% children demonstrated improvement in BLN

title.narrative: Outcome 2.2: Parents and caregivers are better able to support their children’s CP and psychosocial needs

# of parents and caregivers participating in parenting programs (810 (JOR 360; LEB 450)
% of parents and caregivers indicate feeling increased confidence in supporting their children (JOR 70; LEB 55)

target.value:
# of parents and caregivers participating in parenting programs (810 (JOR 360; LEB 450)
% of parents and caregivers indicate feeling increased confidence in supporting their children (JOR 70; LEB 55)

actual.value:
919 (703 women and 216 men) participated in the parenting program (JOR 480; LEB 439)
87% of the parents and caregivers indicated feeling increased confidence in supporting their children.

title.narrative: Outcome 1.1: Recently displaced HHs are able to meet their immediate needs

# Multi-purpose cash grant distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 1,430)
# Ready to Eat Rations distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 800)
# NFI kits distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 800)

target.value:
# Multi-purpose cash grant distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 1,430)
# Ready to Eat Rations distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 800)
# NFI kits distributed to vulnerable families (SYR 800)

actual.value:
A total of 1,618 MPCG was distributed in Syria reaching 8,351 individuals (1,525 male, 1,920 female, 2,407 girls, 2,499 boys). This was overachieved due to savings on salary lines that were allocated to MPGs line to increase the number of targeted HHs. 800 RTERs was distributed in Syria reaching 4,013 individuals (2,358 children, 1,655 adult) in their first two weeks after displacement.
1,111 NFI and hygiene kits distributed to 1,111 vulnerable families reaching 5,713 individuals: 3,344 children, 2369 adults).

title.narrative: Improved protective environment for vulnerable Syrian IDPs, refugee, returnees and host community children affected by grave child rights violations; harmful work and child marriage
Strengthen the protective environment of vulnerable, hard-to-reach and out-of-school children through improved and safe access to quality education pathways suitable to their needs
